column1: How many seats will the Justice and Development Party (AKP) win in Turkey's snap elections?
column6: ['Elections and Referenda', 'Non-US Politics']
Initial reports are that they won a strong majority. Don't know if forecasts will stay open, but... http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34694420
Everything seems quite clear one. Almost all votes are counted. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34694420

Assuming GJ will score this question based on what the polls are reporting, it is necessary to flip my 100% plurality to 100% majority. Anyone think that GJ will score this question based on what the polls "probably" "actually" say? :-|
This looks like they will win a majority of the seats. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/11/turkey-ruling-akp-leads-crucial-snap-elections-151101160104190.html
People want a change.

I think with this snap election the Goverment will restrengthen its grip on power. There is to many issues to have to have a divided legislature. I dont know if it will be this outcome because of the peoples vote or a mix of that an fraud to get the seats they want an need. I think Turkey is slowly moving to a type of dictatorship with this President.
It's over, isn't it?
Whoops
Reports are they won a majority.
There might be fraud, but AKP will get the majority. Any investigation would drag on for months.
They just won a majority; that was unexpected.
It should be closed
http://www.todayszaman.com/home
Darn close. Just under 50% popular vote for AKP, but looks like they have the requisite number of seats. HDP makes it into parliament though.

Forecasted AKP as majority at 80% prior to election, taking him to 100% as they won and since this does not close until Nov 7, not enough time to officially re-tally and investigate if there was fraud. He will take the 'enemies of Turkey' speech further to divide country if violence or international doubts are used to de-legitamize the win.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34694420
Surprisingly AKP is going to win a majority in the current elections, however there is a slight chance of unrest that may result in a failure to form a government (wishful thinking).
http://www.kait8.com/story/30403404/report-preliminary-results-suggest-turkish-ruling-party-win so some are saying above 50% and some just below, so going 50 50 for now (last minute changes

Early results suggest a decrease in support for extreme nationalist MHP to little more than 10% of the vote (compared with 16% at last election, and sharp increase in AKP support, to around 50% (from 41%). Still uncertain if, overall, that the HDP, or indeed the MHP will end up surpassing the 10% threshold for representation. Should either party fail to do so, an AKP absolute majority would seem to be assured. Even without it, the sharp upturn in support for the AKP still seems to make an absolute majority more likely than not

Reconsidering last forecast change - difference in reports on vote % counted. YSK is vote count that matters, much slower - hearing 20% at present. Apparently AA (Anadolu Agency?) typically reports AKP numbers high early - before votes actually officially counted. Still seems like high chance of AKP majority & have been low in that.
http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2015/nov/01/turkey-election-2015-live-updates
ARE YOU KIDDING ME??? AKP ON COURSSE TO MAGICALLY GROW 13% SINCE JUNE??? http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/akp-appears-on-course-to-win-majority-with-half-the-votes-counted.aspx
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/01/us-turkey-election-akp-idUSKCN0SQ23A20151101
70 % vote counted, AKP winning majority according to Aljazeera TV just now so going from 95 to 99 (always better to bet after the votes counted ;-)

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/11/turks-head-polls-crucial-snap-election-151101053150899.html shows AKP with majority in votes already counted so changing to reflect that. Other sources suggested polling surge by AKP (should have been paying attn. to this one ;-)
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34694420
Unless widespread fraud they will again poll in the 40's.

TOP ELECTION COMMISSION SAYS "OF COURSE THE CITIZENS CAN MONITOR THE POLLING PLACES FOR SIGNS OF TAMPERING" http://www.todayszaman.com/national_top-election-body-rejects-banning-civilian-group-from-monitoring-elections_403027.html
Various reports of violence, HDP election bureau in Adana burnt What happens after is good question.

Raising likelihood of a majority on the basis of concerns about fraud increasing, polls showing a fast shift toward AKP. In addition, the government has been imprisoning journalists and warring with the Kurds.
This news could affect the outcome of the vote: http://www.pressreader.com/usa/usa-today-us-edition/20151030/281487865215690/TextView
Updating. The AKP has the resources and has limited the opposition for quite a while to indicate his divisive and autocratic tactics are beginning to move the votes to a majority.
@morrell

Feeling uncomfortable with some polls indicating majority for AKP, as well as entirely possible that sentiment has swung toward stability at any cost. On the other hand, very obvious media crackdown by gov't and reports of gov't punishment for publishing polls indicating AKP will lose seats both undermine my confidence in positive polls. Hedging a bit.

http://news.yahoo.com/poll-sees-ruling-akp-winning-large-majority-turkish-125944846--business.html Two new polls 1)indicates AKP to win a majority as Turks vote for stability 2) Second shows no majority.
Confirming prior forecast

This weeks Economist leader is talking about how AK are engineering power, but is recommending resistance to it, while recognizing the value of Turkey to the West. It has suggested a hung parliament due to opinion polls. I am in two minds over this, on the one hand, the regaining of power is being engineered in various ways which could create a majority, yet on the other, there are many social and economic problems facing citizens and they will want change. I am trying not to be too swayed by the Economists viewpoint per see as the Economist doesn't get a vote in the elections, though some of its readers could apply pressure. I really don't know which way to go on this one. So I will still go for a majority but with a lower percentage, primarily because clever politicians are rather good at engineering power, which could outbalance popular discomfort..
AG&G poll shows majority. However, results of polls in Turkey tend to vary widely.
Based on @Anneinak...
http://news.yahoo.com/poll-sees-ruling-akp-winning-large-majority-turkish-125944846--business.html
http://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2015/oct/28/turkey-election-2015-guide-parties-polls-electoral-system

The Turkish parliament consists of 550 seats. The number of seats needed for a majority government is 278 (¬50.5%) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey#Parliamentary_groups). The threshold for the elections stands on 10%.
Citizens mobilize to prevent voting fraud. Bad news for Ergodan and his thugs.

could go either way, but wondering if gov't raids and suppression of media will end up working against AKP effort to reach majority. Though - could be chaos post-election. Should look for data on election outcomes when pre-election period features increasing violence - not sure if exist TBH.

T-4 AND THE POOP IS GETTING REALER AS RIOTS OUTSIDE OPPOSITION MEDIA AND THREATS OF WHAT'S GONNA HAPPEN AFTER 11/1 http://www.todayszaman.com/latest-news_turkish-police-break-gates-storm-critical-media-group-amid-brawls_402702.html
AKP will win the majority by hook or crook. As AKP had to struggle to get this majority - the country will go under semi-dictatorship.
Following Anne. Thank you for all your hard work!
Had been at 99%, decided that it's time to push it to 100% (re: link from Annienak).

I say majority, because the semi-engaged voters will be shocked to have seen the failure in June and will rally understanding their vote matters to restore their version of "normal". And given the recent unrest from Syria, they will want anything that feels like normal.
The Economist strikes agian
Lagging behind the herd again

http://rudaw.net/english/middleeast/turkey/271020153 - " . . . nearly all opinion polls indicate that the ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) will again fail to get the parlaimentary seats needed to form a majority government. . . . " . . . AKP would need 18 seats more than it won in the June polls to form a majority government. . . . " . . . according to Kemal Ozkriyaz, who runs the Afrasia polling organization, the AKP will even lose some of the votes it had received in June. “AKP’s votes are likely to increase in the Black Sea area and the Middle Anatolian regions, where it can take voters from the MHP,” Ozkriyaz told Rudaw. “But it will only get 40, 45 percent of the overall votes, since it will most probably lose votes in other regions,” he added. Ozkriyaz predicts that the AKP will end up losing four more seats and receive 254 seats this time.
AKP narrows campaign focus as polls show little chance of single rule
http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2015/10/22/Erdogan-seen-with-little-choice-but-to-share-power-after-Turkish-vote/

According to Euronews this morning AK have moved to take control of a critical and crucial media holding. http://www.euronews.com/2015/10/27/turkey-s-ruling-ak-party-moves-to-seize-critical-media-holding-ahead-of-election/ This throws a spanner in the works for me, as the trend in Europe is towards extremism in politics just now (sadly). According to http://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2015/jun/08/turkey-election-results-what-you-need-to-know AKP was 18 seats short of majority, with no other party close. hence my initial thoughts are that this is going to be close, and if Euronews is correct that could sway things in favour of AK.
299 seats - Türks driven to the edge: war-mongering dictator with new palace 30x size of White House vs. some slim hope of peace.
Assume no significant change since last result.
AKP could steal this election. [1]
GOVERNMENT SEIZES ONE MEDIA OUTLET THAT IS CRITICAL OF AKP http://www.todayszaman.com/business_ak-party-govt-seizes-critical-holding-media-groups-a-week-before-polls_402561.html

39 SEATS ARE THE ONLY ONES THAT MATTER. AKP NEEDS 18 OF THEM, AND SOME ARE GOING TO BE REEEEEEEEEEEEALY CLOSE: http://www.todayszaman.com/national_39-critical-constituencies-to-determine-how-parliament-will-be-shaped_402563.html
It would be pleasant not to suspect that AKP will do something sleazy in the next couple of weeks to gain a majority. If they don't, no majority for them; if they do, I think it won't work.
Revised prediction based on latest polls (before 22 oct.)
People disillusioned
People disillusioned.
Erdogan has escalated the conflict with the PKK, Turks will go out to support AKP
Various news and nagging doubts
Unreliable polls indicate plurality result. Very close call. Bombing not helpful for AKP, but Merkel refugee talks is helpful for AKP.
No fundamental change from last elections.
http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/akp-narrows-campaign-focus-as-polls-show-little-chance-of-single-rule.aspx?pageID=238&nID=90262&NewsCatID=338
Following morrell --she's almost always right.

Moving to consensus forecast. A couple further seat prediction polls have been published that show AKP falling short of a majority of seats. Vote share polls have been fairly consistent all along, predicting results similar to June.
I seem to be obligated to make a stab. Erdogan has been a funny customer these past years. Makes the question interesting.
Tactical hedge switch: had majority at approx. 65%, since the GJ median is 10%, no real harm in minimizing the damage from a wrong outcome.
Following Nick Lutz

Like Raisinville is saying, a few polls are right on the line of a majority. But most are still suggesting a plurality. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Turkish_general_election,_November_2015
Moving up probability of majority on @Raisinville's analysis & recent poll data.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Turkish_general_election,_November_2015 Holding forecast on a AKP majority, based on recent poll changes and appearent EU support for a stable Turkey. Seat Count Projections for AKP (post 10 Oct. Ankara bombings): Detimar Poll: 278 seats (a 6 seat majority)
LATEST POLL ANALYSIS: AKP TO GET 1-3%, WHICH MIGHT BE ENOUGH FOR A MAJORITY, BUT PROBABLY WON'T BE: http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/what-to-expect-in-the-upcoming-elections-.aspx

• First we find out that the bombers had MUCHO ammonium-nitrate, and they were planning a truck bombing at HDP HQ during an election rally, until the rally was cancelled for safety reasons. • Then we find out that the bombers decided that THIS rally was a target of opportunity, so they went after it.
Up date

I'm shifting probabilities a little more towards a majority. The reason AKP didn't get a majority last time was because the HDP got more than 10% of the vote share and hence entered parliament. Polls till now indicate that the HDP is likely to retain its vote share this time.

In a September 12th forecast, I wrote that his assets that would change his polling trend were: He could win by declaring he is the war president and wrap the flag around him. He could employ other means to convince and coerce non-supportive party opposition to support him that went to the MHP.
Affirming prior.

In the most recent elections AKP didn't get the majority to form a government, and things got worse for the Party since then (economy is stagnant, the Syria policy has failed, the PKK terror is back, the violations of various rights became more common place and widely reported/accepted, and its mega projects (Kanal Istanbul, etc.) turned out to be bogus).
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/17/us-egypt-election-monitors-idUSKCN0SB0BR20151017
small increase in chances for a majority, due to talks between Turkey and Germany/EU on the refugee crisis. A possible boon for Erdogan.

Polling is looking pretty similar to last time, but they weren't that far from a majority before. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Turkish_general_election,_November_2015 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Turkish_general_election,_June_2015
returning high on ysk rulings

Turkey - EU deal might give AK a lift toward majority: Effective sanction relief, renewed EU integration, Extra cash, support from opposition political parties, a softer AK image, and possibly, political stability.
Affirming prior forecast.

update downgrading "a majority" influenced by mike97mike reference (thanks to him) http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/turkeys-snap-elections-may-not-change-much but the poll is before the terrorist attack. Do i put too much importance on this matter?
There is always a chance?
Affirming forecast of 19 September.
AIN'T NO MOUNTAIN: AKP STUCK AT 40% IN LATEST GEZICI POLL: http://www.todayszaman.com/national_turkish-poll-shows-ruling-ak-party-support-short-of-majority_401564.html

"Opposition parties have voiced their concern about the potential of the interim government, which is led by the Justice and Development Party (Adalet ve Kalkinma Partisi: AKP), taking advantage of the state of disorder in the southeast to manipulate the election in the AKP's favour." http://www.janes.com/article/55247/turkish-attacks-on-pkk-and-retaliation-against-security-forces-in-southeast-remain-likely-despite-unilateral-pkk-ceasefire

1: The opinions and concerns that resulted in the last election result have not altered to suggest a change in overall outcome. http://www.pewglobal.org/2015/10/15/deep-divisions-in-turkey-as-election-nears/ 2: The next election (after 2015) will be 2019 and it is unlikely that the population will allow any party sole control of the country for that period of time.

The AKP dropped from 50% last year to 42%, their nearest rival is the CHP who is nearing 30%, not enough for either to have a majority and not enough for a coalition with the AKP because they lack the support from other parties who can form a strong government for quite a while.
SHOCK! ONE OF THE SUICIDE BOMBERS IS THE BROTHER OF ONE OF THE BOMBERS IN SURUC! http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/two-suicide-bombers-in-ankara-massacre-identified-.aspx

Maintaining Prediction, based on logic from the attached link: "Lastly, it should be remembered that the AKP was only short of 18 parliamentarians after the June elections; thus, what the AKP is after is what I would term ‘surgical interventions’ in certain localities. This time what might determine the outcome may not be the overall votes the AKP receives (unless they experience a serious drop in votes, bringing them below 40 per cent), but the ‘extra parliamentarians’ they could win in highly contested constituencies." http://www.socialeurope.eu/2015/10/why-turkeys-repeat-elections-in-november-are-unlikely-to-ease-the-countrys-political-tensions/
Following ousel, Heffalump.
Here comes the unrest: nationwide strikes as funerals held: http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/ankara-bombing-spurs-nationwide-strikes-as-funerals-being-held.aspx?pageID=238&nID=89774&NewsCatID=341
- Base line is the June election result. - Recent polling shows the election result being split largely across similar lines.
Bombings have increased possibility that govt suppresses HDP votes to the point that they don't make the 10% threshold. (Very useful to follow @Zeynep Tufekci on Twitter.)

With the 10 October bombings in Ankara, AKP will be lucky to keep the 41% they had in June. On the other hand, if the culprits behind the Ankara bombing turn out to be Kurds, AKP's election results could improve, and HDP's will sink like a stone, restoring the AKP majority. I'd be a little surprised if Kurds were behind it, though. It wouldn't be the mainline PKK behind it.

Last election (AKP) Ahmet Davutoğlu 258 40,66%, (CHP) Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu 132 25,13%, (MHP) Devlet Bahçeli 80 16,45%, (HDP) Selahattin Demirtaş and Figen Yüksekdağ 80 12,96%, Others 4,80% 40,66 % it's close to 50%. If we look where they live, it's seems not in large cities, where for the same number of votes, their a number larger of seats. In the other side, 15 to 30 % of the population could identify himself like something else than turks. Can those parties be illegal soon? Who can makes "terrorist attacks"? what for? from Inside or outside? Whatever, it will polarize the population, peaceful mind people could be seen like traitors to the nation when they face an enemy near the border or in the sky.

Aggregation of the latest polls (including my own proprietary one) through an accuracy and timedecay models as of NOW = Plurality http://oltac.unsal.com/post/129219617814/se%C3%A7im-tahmininizi-yap%C4%B1n

The terrorist strike in Ankara on 10/10 will further divide the parties as to whether or not Mr Erdogan and the AKP could have better secured the area or if his policies had provoked the bombings or if his actions and policies are ineffective in near region and domestic policy. The immediate blame on the Kurds may lead to further anti-AKP cynicism if the Kurds are not the ones who were the bombers. Whomever did it the activity, the event further co-relates with my 10/9 forecast on the open question of 2016 that Turkey will look inward as it manages it fractured domestic, near border, and military policies.
Increasing likelihood of a majority as Kurdish-related violence spreads. Where is the Kurdish version of Martin Luther King?

I was shocked that all the efforts to rig this election last time failed, they'll be more careful this time, the rigging will add up right and AKP will probably get to the 66% level Erdogan needs to make his changes.

UPDATE: PKK attacks police in southeast (before bombing in Ankara), declares cease-fire until after election: http://www.todayszaman.com/national_2-police-officers-killed-in-attacks-before-pkk-declares-cease-fire_401145.html
BREAKING: Twin-bombings in Ankara kill 97 Guardian: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/10/turkey-suicide-bomb-killed-in-ankara

More explosions than one might prefer have been associated with this campaign. Several viable candidates for perpetrator(s), but Erdogan will in any case use them as an excuse for a crackdown on anyone who might vote against him. Turks, unlike Americans, are not easily frightened, so this may well backfire. He still won't get a majority.
EU may see the practical benefits to a stable government in Turkey:
Hmmm, let me count the ways Turkey's people ought to be increasingly worried.
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/08/us-turkey-kurds-ceasefire-idUSKCN0S21V220151008
Clamping down on the opposition press and demonization of the Kurds are unsavory tactics but ones that have worked around the world historically. Control of the ballot boxes can also be helpful

So what happens if something lethal happens between Russia and Turkey before November 1? http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/turkey-syria-russia-airspace-violations-militants-infiltrate.html

http://www.todayszaman.com/national_govt-led-intimidation-operations-increase-prior-to-nov-1-election_400475.html Erdogan and his henchthugs continue to try to bully people into not voting, or to make it impossible or at least difficult to do so. This is not unlikely to backfire. AKP will get a plurality, but they may even lose some seats as a result of all this. In any case, they probably can't pull off enough stunts to gain a majority, short of outlawing at least two other parties in some arcane way. They may try this, but the recent court decision forbidding them to move ballot boxes around is somewhat heartening. So AKP will not get a majority this time, and will call another election for early next year. When that doesn't work, Erdogan will get really nasty. Stay tuned.
http://m.yenisafak.com/en/election/turkey-election-latest-polls-signal-ak-party-victory-2316846
Will be close,but probably will hit the 40% threshold.
Polls still showing plurality (low 40's), getting closer to election, not a lot of variance in polls, so upping to 95 PLU and 5
Thought I was at this already - keep losing track. Looks a lot like June...

Government attacks against journalists and their publishers continue to worsen. Will this help the ruling AKP or hurt it? Polls suggest the attacks are backfiring. http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/turkey-government-mount-pressure-on-media-ahead-of-elections.html; also thank you, Rote, for your data, thank you, Heffalump, for the betting stats.
Following others.

Starting to look like Erdogan can't figure out how to rig this election fast enough to save it for himself. He could still outlaw some party or arrest some bunch of people at just about the last minute, but that mayn't work this time. If he doesn't get a majority in this election, another snap election will follow in less than six months. Not every would-be president-for-life is clever.

Correction error, flipped the percentage forecast. The AKP is falling in the polls. PM Davutoğlu is very unpopular and ranks at 4% when people are asked who was the best PM. When asked of Mr. Erdogan, the numbers declined from a previous 36% to 30% in one month. Asked of the current state of Turkey dropped from 34 percent in May to 15 percent in September. In response to the question, “How do you evaluate the AKP’s performance?” those answering “unsuccessful” increased by 14 points to 58 percent. But when asked, 88% said they would not vote for another party. ("Polls show no difference from Turkey’s June election," 2015). The AKP will win, but gain less support than in June
Thank you, Heffalump, for this tip.

Betting markets say Plurality, not Majority: http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/infographics-betting-on-the-nov-1-election.aspx?pageID=238&nID=89415&NewsCatID=338 HDP to "easily" clear 10%, CHP and MHP to get about the same number of votes as last time, AKP "more likely to score below 40.6%"
Affirming prior.

News from #cmeinel wants me to move a few more to maj, vs. http://en.trend.az/world/turkey/2439948.html which makes me want to go back up to higher plu. Was happily sat with high %plu until #raisinville gave me cause for concern. This ruling makes me think the shenanigans they are trying will be harder to pull off; but clearly AKP is going all out if the most popular daily newspaper editor resigns. On balance, saying AKP less likely to pull off this upset. But will wait to see if editors protest worked (i.e news remains fair) or if the new editor yields.
Media accuracy warning: the Turkish newspaper Today's Zaman is at risk for censorship of stories against Egodan and his AKP, false stories in support of them.
A majority requires a swing of 8-12% Not a plurality requires a bigger swing of 20%
Consistent pollling suggests plurality but not majority: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Turkish_general_election,_November_2015

Today the YSK said the government can't move the ballot boxes. Erdogan is furious, because turnout in the Kurdish areas will doubtless be rather a lot higher than it would have been if the move had worked. Erdogan is disavowing any responsibility for the violence he will foment to prevent turnout, but it looks much more like he'll have to settle for a plurality this time. One may expect him to call another snap election pretty soon, before which he will have outlawed most other parties or jailed their leaders. Nice guy.

Is the AKP now answering to the military? I've been concerned, for a while, that this would happen. http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/10/turkey-military-is-not-willing-to-intervene-politics-for-now.html

Looks like the HDP aren't planning to boycott, but the government is still making as many adjustments as it can get away with to hold down Kurds' participation. They have taken to arresting people for insulting the president, for example. It will be harder to stifle the CHP, who with whatever the HDP can pick up should be able to keep AKP from getting enough votes to make Erdogan president-for-life. It is not likely to be a clean election.

I'm not so sure now - a couple of seat projections give AKP a majority, although by a tiny margin https://tr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kas%C4%B1m_2015_T%C3%BCrkiye_genel_se%C3%A7imleri_i%C3%A7in_yap%C4%B1lan_anketler

Polls here are notoriously unreliable, but as Rick Perry pointed out, even a broken clock is right once a day. The AKP lead is substantial and steady. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Turkish_general_election,_November_2015
beating up independent journalists never a good sign. another 2% to maj.
The government seems to have stepped up its campaign to stifle the pro-Kurdish and other opposition vote. They can't be too overt about their intentions, but they're not fooling anybody any more.

@raisinville, wow that made me stop and think. Following you down, but just cant go as as far as you yet. The below reports show the ballot boxes and sudden growth of voters are a concern to support your thinking though. Think I need to sleep on it a day or to longer before I can shake my previous feeling that the PR system would take care of itself, in that how they could take the PR system (polling 40%) and move that up to a majority. Will watch the ballot box issue closely, and try and spend more time looking at the growth in numbers vs. the borderline districts etc. http://national.bgnnews.com/senior-akp-figure-sahin-admits-ysk-not-authorized-to-transfer-ballot-boxes-haberi/9889 http://national.bgnnews.com/22-provinces-too-close-to-call-for-upcoming-turkish-election-haberi/9731 http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkeys-problem-of-election-security.aspx?PageID=238&NID=89012&NewsCatID=503
Updating for the passage of time

Turkish writer concerned that AKP only needs 50,000 votes in 20 districts to make up for lost seats, and regain a majority. http://www.todayszaman.com/columnist/i-hsan-yilmaz/an-open-letter-to-the-osce-about-the-turkish-election_400258.html

AKP is in power and too far ahead in the polls to suddenly collapse. NON unlikely. Currently at 40.8% and projections show that number holding. Squelching the Kurdish vote will buy some votes in the near-term but will force a coalition, making it more difficult to take a majority.

Looks like Erdogan's lads have started their maneuvers to make it hard for the opposition, especially the Kurds, to vote--moving polling places, for example, and having PM Davotoglu issue warnings that the HDP had better comply with the various laws (which have sometimes been subject to change without notice). There are mutterings about an HDP boycott. Any combination of these things could result in an AKP majority big enough to amend the constitution so Erdogan can be President-for-Life. Probably have to watch this daily.
In for a penny in for a pound.
Oh, nice: CHP/MHP MIGHT be working on a coalition to overcome AKP http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/hdp-co-chair-signals-coalition-with-chp.aspx
updating, polls
Events in east have been claiming somewhat, though still bad. Still giving 35% chance of security event keeping HDP votes artificially low and HDP not crossing threshold.

Polls haven't shown any significant variation in the last couple of weeks. With only 5-weeks to go, change is unlikely. Wildcard: If the ruling party tries to disenfranchise some Kurdish areas, gaining a majority in the rest. Probability is so low that it is not worth considering unless we see evidence in that direction.

One key issue is how the voting will take place in the troubled Southeast. If it is done under martial law, or a version of it where voters are carried to the voting locations by the police/army, 1. this would most certainly scare away a sizeable portion of the HDP sympathisers, and 2. it would make election fraud easier.

The AKP had 41% in the previous election and needs 18 more seats for a majority. Current polls have their support percent remaining relatively the same or slightly higher but not above 50%. Potential factors for changes include political scandals or further conflict with the PKK or ISIL that would change voters minds. Recent minister resignations and moves do not seem to have affected the polls but could in the future. It is extremely unlikely that AKP would not be a plurality but is possible if something large enough were to occur so I give that case 2%, a plurality similar to the previous election is the most likely case and I give that 83%. A change in sentiment given a political or conflict event is possible, shifting AKP to a majority and I give that a 15% possibility.

Though polls show Erdogan's support slipping somewhat, it would be foolish to overlook his long history of success in the face of challenge. His government has provoked a conflict with the Kurdish separatist forces in the southeast with the intent of dismantling broader support for the Kurdish HDP, the party seeking political solutions to the Kurd/Turk conflict. Though, this hasn't had significant effect thus far, all that is necessary is to push support for the HDP below the 10% threshold necessary for parliamentary representation. Unfortunately, the PKK is playing their role in this almost perfectly for Erdogan, though this may not be accidental if the leadership of the PKK is jealous of the successes the HDP had with political engagement in the last election.

This just in: Turkey’s state-controlled Radio and Television Supreme Council (RTÜK) has reportedly banned 15 pro-Kurdish TV stations broadcasting in the country. Among the channels banned are Özgür Gün TV, Dengbej TV and Mezopotamya TV, reports say. The ban comes amidst increasing pressure on the media in Turkey. The Turkish police raided and briefly detained the managing editor of the Nokta magazine on accusations of "propagating terror" and "insulting President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan” through its latest edition depicting a smiling Erdoğan taking a selfie with the flag-draped coffin of a soldier in the background. http://www.todayszaman.com/national_turkeys-media-watchdog-bans-15-pro-kurdish-tv-channels_399140.html

Erdogan wants not only a majority but a supermajority so he can push through some changes to the Constitution which would give him more power. If I was a Turk, I might be persuaded to vote for his party to make government work more efficiently, but I also might be apprehensive about voting for the party which wants to change the constitution for one man's benefit. I see these as balancing factors which will play out as a plurality, not a majority for AKP.

Erdogan's policies regarding the Kurds are likely to have made Turkish politics more partizan (pro/contra Erdogan in particular). This would mean a similar result as the previous time (plurality). In the previous election, the question whether the HDP would have enough votes to pass the election threshold was an important one. The fact that it did pass the threshold last time, does not mean that it will this time. Should the HDP not pass the threshold, a majority for the AKP becomes a likely outcome.

Definitions of the parties for the Turkish situation

The opposition to the AKP is too divided (as well as ideologically incoherent), and, in many parts of the country, too marginal, to give any of its elements the edge over the AKP. The 10% threshold for representation also serves to benefit the AKP, particularly. At the June elections the AKP held 46.9% of the seats (on a 40.9% share of the vote) - it still appears substantially more likely that they would obtain a majority than less than a plurality. The performance of the HDP (the fourth party in the current parliament) - and indeed, their ability to retain representation by staying over 10% - may be one of the key factors in determining whether the AKP do obtain a majority of seats or not.

Current polls give AKP about 42% of the vote, and CHP about 27%. So AKP has a 15% edge with 2 months to go. Turkish polls seem to be fairly reliable and reasonably stable, so AKP is rather unlikely to lose that lead before the election (so they'll almost certainly win a plurality). On the other hand, AKP would need to increase their vote total by 8% (or a bit less) to form a majority. This is still a large margin to overcome.

Oh, wow, like I haven't been doing enough reading on Turkey and Turkish politics for the last three months. It has been painful to watch. MHP should have been the junior partner, and instead they played spoiled rich kid. CHP seemed like they genuinely tried, a little, but they didn't really try. HDP had no shot. Then PKK and IS both decide now is a good time to all but declare war inside Turkey, and E keeps acting like he's got this in the bag, while D does his best lap-dog impersonation. The only way this seems to have any shot at happening is if AKP takes seats from MHP, because I can't imagine HDP losing seats, now that Turkey is bombing Kurds in Iraq, too. MHP certainly has been acting like it doesn't want to exist, any more, but can you imagine them intentionally giving E the keys to changing the constitution so he can have more executive power?

I don't quite understand why the call for an election, but I figure it is along the lines of nothing ventured, nothing gained, and worse case is that he ends up in a similar position, that is without a majority.
